 I too think "Hard Times" to be a great film. By far the best role Bronson ever had. I watch it every time it comes on.

I've always felt that "The Godfather" was the best movie I have ever seen. That may also be one of the reasons I hold to my hard line views about terrorists. Kill them before they kill you. Vito Corleone knew how to deal with his enemies. Of course these were not "good guys" but they did what they did to survive in the world they inhabited. And no, I'm not apologizing for gangsters which the Mafia is and was in the U.S. It has virtually been wiped out though.
 
 I also liked "Will Penney" and "Monte Walsh" very much as I am a big western fan. Those movies are among my small collection of movies I sit down and watch again when the mood strikes. Must be something about the evil that befell the main characters and what had to be done. Most of today's movies really aren't worth watching the first time.

I too think "Hard Times" to be a great film. By far the best role Bronson ever had. I watch it every time it comes on.

 
 Hard Times is one of my all time favs. It has the setting that I really like in a movie - two people meet by accident, and the movie is about the extrordinary things they do together, and they part company in the end. "The Flim Flam Man" (George C. Scott) is like that too. A somewhat lighthearted movie, but at the tender age of 15 when I first saw it, taught me one of life's most important lessons IMO. "you can't cheat an honest man". Scott held up two fingers on each hand to quote it as he said it. Surprisingly true most of the time.
 
 Some others
 
 Kelly's Hero's
 Shenendoa
 The Sons of Katie Elder
 Mr. Majestyk
 Silver Streak
 
 and others already mentioned (to make my 10 :) )
 
 The Great Escape
 Shawshank Redemption
 Wizard of Oz

Here are some of my personal favourites, by genre.
 
 Horror: The Shining (scary in so many ways!)
 
 Western: Once Upon a Time in the West (the definitive spagetti western!)
 
 Science fiction: Alien (outstanding in every regard)
 
 Thriller: Basic Instinct (actually, throw Robocop and Starship Troopers in as well- Vernhofen is wonderfully subversive!)
 
 War: tie between Cross of Iron and Das Boot (the losing side perspective gets rid of Jingoism nicely)
 
 Life & Love: Terms of Endearment
 
 Oh-my-god-what-has-happened-to-my-mind-movies: Tie between Memento and Fight Club
 
 Prison: Shawshank Redemption (one of the handful of films I watch again on a regualr basis).
 
 Courtroom drama: Twelve Angry Men (one of Henry Fonda's finest)
 
 Crime: Bullitt (brilliant style and direction, plus the best car chase in movie history, bar none!)
 
 
 If you have not seen any of these, do!
 
 
 P.S. Okay, I'm cheating with an eleventh catajory:
 
 Most amazing scene change in movie history: 2001 (its a bone......... no its a spaceship!) :p

 Damn! Are we allowed only 10?

1) Transformers: The Movie - Lame, I know, but growing up, Optimus Prime was like the male role model for all the kids my age - his death was shocking to us all. It's the movie for the ADD generation - if you have a 30 second attention span, this movie is for you. Oh and the classic lines - Galvatron "Would anyone else like to fill his shooons?"
 
 And I hate 80s music, but it's loaded with it, and its good "You got the touch. You got the power! Yeah!"
 
 2) Terminator 2 - Everyone else who loves this movie seems to be a testosterone fuelled XXXXX - I appreciated its philosophical content more than anything else "No fate but what you make for yourself". Plus it was cool. Still is.

Oh yeah!
 
 I loved Alien and Twelve Monkeys.
 
 Also, there's Mixed Nuts with Steve Martin, and Juliet Lewis, and then there was this movie that HBO made a number of years ago about a potential World War Three, called  ... and by Dawn's Early Light

My Best List
 
 Glory - Best Civil War Movie bar none
 Henry V - The best of the Bard
 Big Lebowski "Nobody ***** with the Jesus!"
 Rushmore - Bill Murray at his craggiest
 Duck Soup - Marx Brother's perfection
 Rudy - Go Irish
 Saving Private Ryan: "Earn This" 
 Braveheart: "Every man dies, not everyman truly lives"
 The Searchers: Best of John Wayne
 North by Northwest - Hitchcock
 
 Worst Movies of all Time
 
 Hope Floats: Maudlin. I fell asleep, woke up and the kid was STILL crying
 Pearl Harbor - "OK, so I'm like seeing this guy and then Oh My GOD!!! The harbor gets like bombed and I'm like...wow..." I would rather eat dryer lint than watch this film
 
 Wind Talkers: Where we learn that Nicolas Cage single handedly won WWII
 Thin Red Line: I was rooting for the Japanese after the first inane voice over.
 The Departed: I never cared less about characters in any other movie. Profanity, head shots, roll credits. 
 
 Literally ANY movie with Sandra Bullock
 Any movie whose promo starts with "soundtrack by...."
 Batman and Robin: This movie cannot, by law, be shown to prisoners of war
 Blair Witch Project: A toothache of a movie
 Highlander II: Wretched and inexplicable
Solaris? You've got to be kidding!
What are you talking about? Solaris rocked! It did every mood perfectly! It never told you too much. It was a mystery/scifiwhatif/drama/romance/everything sort of movie! It was perfect!

Thin red line was AWEFUL! ahahahah! Terrible! 
 
 My reenactment of any given scene in TRL:
 
 [Spoken with an overdone southern twang] "Am I my brothers Keeper?" 
 
 [pause 20 seconds while we watch vague, unrelated footage] 
 "Who is my brother that I should love him?" 
 
 [30 seconds of silence and still the vague, unrelated footage] "Wait, what was this movie about again? Oh yeah thats right, its about prison soilders in a dishonored regiment whining like its 1998, and they joined for college money and beer."
 
 
 The scene where they're beating on the hatch in the hold of the ship and yelling "let us out, let us out" is the most telling scene in the whole movie. Hollywood would rather focus on a bunch of pathetic malcontent SOILDERS in the Pacific theatre than on the real fighters : THE MARINES. The Army distinguished themselves in the European theatre and the Marines distinguished themselves in the Pacific theatre. It was the worst context for an antiwar film I have ever seen. Defeatist to the core. God I hated that movie!

My Best List
 Worst Movies of all Time
 
 Pearl Harbor - "OK, so I'm like seeing this guy and then Oh My GOD!!! The harbor gets like bombed and I'm like...wow..." I would rather eat dryer lint than watch this film

 LMAO!
 I would definitely include that on my list as well. Have you seen Team America: World Police? They do a hilarious song about that movie in it.
 
 As far as worst movies, that's harder. I tend to forget about the bad ones. But from what I can remember at the moment I'd say:
 G.I. Jane- One of the few movies in my life I've actually walked out on.
 The English Patient- Easily the single most boring movie I've ever seen in my life. I wish I could be more clever about this, but that would have required the film to give me some material to work with.
 Saw II- Screw plot! Lets just smash people's heads!

Also in no order:
 
 Dr Strangelove
 Brazil
 Alien
 A Shot in the Dark
 American Beauty
 A Clockwork Orange
 From Dusk till Dawn
 Life of Brian
 The New World
 Rope
 
 edit:
 
 
Offhand I would say:
 
 Dr Strangelove
 Alien
 The Life of Brian
 Brazil
 A Clockwork Orange

 Reservoir Dogs
 Metropolis
 Batman
 Zulu
 
 Though those would probably change if you asked me tomorrow!
Gagh! And they did change. Forgotten I'd already replied to this!

1. Blackhawk Down -or-
 1. Black Hawk Down

 5. Any other war movie
 
 6. Everything else, except:

No particular order:
 
 JFK - OK this is number 1 but the rest are in no order.
 Anchorman - American comedy that actually makes me laugh!
 Nausicaa - Early anime by the guy who did Spirited Away - weird and awesome.
 Munich - Very thought-provoking; everyone should see it.
 South Park - Best musical ever written.
 Apocalypse Now - Mesmerising. Horrifying. Beautiful.
 Being John Malkovich - Just so weird that I have to love it.
 A Clockwork Orange - Needs no explanation.
 Casino - much better than Scarface
 Ong Bak - best martial arts since Bruce Lee
 
 Plus all De Niro's films; finest actor of his generation.
 
 And just for the hell of it, the definitive worst: Kangaroo Jack. Why? Just...why?

OK, since we have revived this horse so we can beat on it a little longer:
 
 Dogma...Since I didn't say it before (hilarious)
 The Enemy Below (Robert Mitchum...best actor of his time)
 Run Silent Run Deep (Clark Gable, Burt Lancaster, and Don Rickles all in the same movie...almost makes me poop)
 12' O'clock High (Gregory Peck...second best actor of his time)
 Midway (Star-studded cast, acurate and unembellished, actual footage)
 Flags of our Fathers (Clint Eastwood...
 Letters from Iwo Jima ...will never be too old to direct great movies)
 ...Pretty much any other well done WWII movie...
 Bringing out the Dead (I've had weeks like that)
 Family Guy Movie ("Isn't there an 'O' in country?")
 The Money Pit (...Yale...Phi Betta Kappa)
 
 Worst movies I have ever seen...at least parts of)
 
 English Patient -Just die already
 Sleepless in Seattle -Better known as sleeping on my couch
 E.T. -Yeah...I got a finger for ya
 Star Wars (all 67 of them) -They sucked....plain and simple, get over it
